channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Ventura County trails to remain closed through September amid coronavirus concerns
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Part of Santa Paula Canyon — from the forest boundary to about three miles above the Punch Bowl — will remain off-limits as officials look to stave off potential crowding.
item.content:encoded: Part of Santa Paula Canyon — from the forest boundary to about three miles above the Punch Bowl — will remain off-limits as officials look to stave off potential crowding.

media:content.media:description: Highway 33 winds through the mountains of the Los Padres National Forest in Ventura County.
media:content.media:credit: Michael Robinson Chavez / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Five residents file lawsuit alleging LAPD falsely labeled them as gang members
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Five residents allege in a lawsuit that LAPD officers labeled them gang members without evidence as part of a pattern of corruption that has caused irreparable harm to them and others.
item.content:encoded: Five residents allege in a lawsuit that LAPD officers labeled them gang members without evidence as part of a pattern of corruption that has caused irreparable harm to them and others.

media:content.media:description: A woman who fell out of a moving Los Angeles police car has reached a settlement with the city and officers.

item.title: Frank Ocean's teen brother, Ryan Breaux, reportedly killed in Thousand Oaks car crash
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Social media identified the 18-year-old as one of two people killed in a crash early Sunday. CSUN said the other victim was student Ezekial Bishop.
item.content:encoded: Social media identified the 18-year-old as one of two people killed in a crash early Sunday. CSUN said the other victim was student Ezekial Bishop.

media:content.media:description: A crash in Thousand Oaks left two dead.

item.title: Wildfire in Colusa County chars more than 500 acres
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Sites fire began Sunday afternoon in Colusa County, northwest of Sacramento. Firefighters made significant progress in containing the blaze overnight.
item.content:encoded: The Sites fire began Sunday afternoon in Colusa County, northwest of Sacramento. Firefighters made significant progress in containing the blaze overnight.

media:content.media:description: The Sites fire has burned more than 500 acres in Colusa County, northwest of Sacramento.

item.title: LAUSD, teachers reach tentative deal for more predictable remote learning schedules for students
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Students will have a more predictable learning schedule under an agreement between the teachers union and L.A. Unified over what teaching will look like while campuses are closed due to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Students will have a more predictable learning schedule under an agreement between the teachers union and L.A. Unified over what teaching will look like while campuses are closed due to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: School desk and chairs in empty modern classroom. Empty class room with white board and projector in elementary school. Primary classroom with smartboard and alphabet on wall.

item.title: Apple fire swells to 26,000 acres amid hot, dry and windy conditions
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The fire has burned 26,450 acres and was 5% contained as of Monday morning.
item.content:encoded: The fire has burned 26,450 acres and was 5% contained as of Monday morning.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters set back fires as the leading edge of the Apple fire rages towards the Oak Canyon Conservation Camp near Beaumont on Saturday.

item.title: Column: Chop down the lynching tree from this California city's logo? Probably not so fast
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: The fight to retire Placerville's noose should serve as a warning, in this time of support for Black Lives Matter, that change will not happen quickly.
item.content:encoded: The fight to retire Placerville's noose should serve as a warning, in this time of support for Black Lives Matter, that change will not happen quickly.

media:content.media:description: "George," a life-sized mannequin, hangs from the side of a building in downtown Placerville in July 2020.
media:content.media:credit: Erika D. Smith/ Los Angeles Times

item.title: California unemployment agency workers say internal problems are stalling claims process
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: As California grapples with a deluge of requests for unemployment benefits during the pandemic, government workers tasked with processing claims say they are hampered by outdated technology, bureaucratic red tape and a shortage of trained staff.
item.content:encoded: As California grapples with a deluge of requests for unemployment benefits during the pandemic, government workers tasked with processing claims say they are hampered by outdated technology, bureaucratic red tape and a shortage of trained staff.

media:content.media:description: CANOGA PARK, CA - MAY 14: Brenda Bermudez came looking for information about her unemployment claim but found the California State Employment Development Department closed on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Canoga Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: This L.A. hunter killed an elephant. Now he's a PETA target in bid to end trophy hunting
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: California may soon pass a law to ban the import of "trophy" animal parts from Africa. Activists are targeting an L.A. hunter whose hunt was captured on video.
item.content:encoded: California may soon pass a law to ban the import of "trophy" animal parts from Africa. Activists are targeting an L.A. hunter whose hunt was captured on video.

media:content.media:description: An African elephant in the wild.

item.title: Some autopsies remain secret for years. Families of those killed by police want that changed
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Some coroners' reports on the famous and not-so-famous are kept from the public.
item.content:encoded: Some coroners' reports on the famous and not-so-famous are kept from the public.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER VILLAGE, CA - JULY 27: Albert Corado is the brother of Mely Corado who was killed by the LAPD two years ago at the Trader Joe's in Silver Lake. Her autopsy remains under a "security hold," which blocks disclosure of her autopsy to the public. Photographed at Atwater Village on Monday, July 27, 2020. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus hospitalizations drop in L.A., Orange counties
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Public health officials said they are hopeful that actions taken over the last few weeks have slowed the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Public health officials said they are hopeful that actions taken over the last few weeks have slowed the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Sun-baked Southern California expected to cool off by Wednesday, according to weather service
item.dc:creator: Adam Elmahrek
item.description: The heatwave that has baked the region is expected to ease on Monday, with relief and a noticeable drop in temperatures by the middle of the week.
item.content:encoded: The heatwave that has baked the region is expected to ease on Monday, with relief and a noticeable drop in temperatures by the middle of the week.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - JULY 32, 2020. An ice cream vendors pushes a cart along the sand at Junipero Beach in Long Beach on a warm Friday afternoon, July 31, 2020. A heat wave is expected to grip Southern California through the weekend, with inland temperatures reaching triple digits. (Luis Sinco/Los Aneles Time)

item.title: 'Everything is over the top': How O.C. hair salons work through the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Andrew Turner
item.description: After securing a permit from the city, TravisVu the Salon on Warner Avenue opened again for business last week. Three chairs were set outside under the shade of a roof for clients to arrive after having booked appointments.
item.content:encoded: After securing a permit from the city, TravisVu the Salon on Warner Avenue opened again for business last week. Three chairs were set outside under the shade of a roof for clients to arrive after having booked appointments.

media:content.media:description: Travis Vu, 47 of Anaheim, finishes cutting the hair of client Thuy Ngo outside Travis Vu The Salon, in Fountain Valley on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020. Vu is now able to operate in the open air following guidelines set by the city because of the coronavirus Covid-19.

item.title: Firefighters struggle to control Apple fire in Riverside County as winds pick up
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry
item.description: California's first major wildfire of the year grew to more than 20,000 acres overnight after destroying one home and forcing thousands to evacuate.
item.content:encoded: California's first major wildfire of the year grew to more than 20,000 acres overnight after destroying one home and forcing thousands to evacuate.

media:content.media:description: A firefighter from Carpinteria monitors a huge plume of smoke from the Apple fire along Bluff Street, north of Banning.

item.title: Marines identify 8 servicemen presumed dead after training accident off San Clemente Island
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Carlos Lozano
item.description: The Marines late Sunday released the names of eight U.S. servicemen who went missing during a training exercise off San Clemente Island last week.
item.content:encoded: The Marines late Sunday released the names of eight U.S. servicemen who went missing during a training exercise off San Clemente Island last week.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. flag was lowered to half-staff at Park Semper Fi in San Clemente, Calif., on Friday, July 31, 2020. Officials say a military seafaring assault vehicle with 15 Marines and a Navy sailor aboard sank off the coast of Southern California, leaving one of the Marines dead and eight missing. A Marine Corps spokesman says they were traveling in the amphibious assault vehicle from the shores of San Clemente Island to a Navy ship Thursday evening when they reported that the vehicle was taking on water. (Paul Bersebach/The Orange County Register via AP)

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 3.1 quake hits near San Jose
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: The earthquake was reported Sunday morning at 5:40 a.m. Pacific time less than a mile from San Jose, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: The earthquake was reported Sunday morning at 5:40 a.m. Pacific time less than a mile from San Jose, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A quake Sunday struck less than a mile from San Jose, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: 'They can't silence us.' Instagram accounts recount racism at L.A.'s elite private schools
item.dc:creator: Jill R. Shah
item.description: Students and alumni from the L.A.'s most exclusive private high schools have launched Instagram campaigns sharing stories of racism and bias on campus.
item.content:encoded: Students and alumni from the L.A.'s most exclusive private high schools have launched Instagram campaigns sharing stories of racism and bias on campus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 29: Sikkiim Hamilton photographed at her Los Angeles home created the @blackatoakwood instagram account highlighting racism at her Oakwood High School located in North Hollywood where she was once a student. Los Angeles on Wednesday, July 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Manhattan Beach was once home to Black beachgoers, but the city ran them out. Now it faces a reckoning
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia
item.description: Before Manhattan Beach shut it down, Bruce's Beach was a famous Black-owned beach resort. Now, some want the city to atone for its actions.
item.content:encoded: Before Manhattan Beach shut it down, Bruce's Beach was a famous Black-owned beach resort. Now, some want the city to atone for its actions.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - JULY 30: Scenes from historic Bruce's Beach at 26th Street and Highland Avenue, in Manhattan Beach, CA, photographed Thursday, July 30, 2020. Some of the land making up Bruce's Beach was purchased by African American couple Willa and Charles Bruce, in 1912, establishing a resort that was open to African Americans. But by the 1920s, racial tensions grew in the beach community and the city condemned the properties. The park was renamed multiple times over the next 80 years and in 2007, was re-named for the Bruce family, responsible for trying to bring change and equality to the city. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A.-area parking spots have become dining areas during the pandemic. Will it last?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: With coronavirus cases surging and indoor dining banned, cities are letting struggling restaurants use sidewalks, parking spaces and private lots to serve meals.
item.content:encoded: With coronavirus cases surging and indoor dining banned, cities are letting struggling restaurants use sidewalks, parking spaces and private lots to serve meals.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 25: Brandon Astudillo, center and wife Rose Astudillo, of Glendale, dine outdoors at Baracoa Cuban Cafe in Atwater Village on Saturday, July 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Restaurant on-site dining limited to outdoor seating due to Covid-19 restrictions in Southern California. Most of the tables are being set up on wide sidewalk areas, or in parking spaces adjacent to the restaurants. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: George Floyd protests: Black police officers see fight for racial justice through personal lens
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Nicole Santa Cruz
item.description: Black law enforcement leaders say they are uniquely equipped to understand the racism embedded in the criminal justice system, the history of oppression of their community and how that has sowed decades of distrust of the police.
item.content:encoded: Black law enforcement leaders say they are uniquely equipped to understand the racism embedded in the criminal justice system, the history of oppression of their community and how that has sowed decades of distrust of the police.

media:content.media:description: SAN BERNARDINO, CA -JULY27: San Bernardino County Sheriff's Deputy Chief Horace Boatwright, center, speaks at an early morning briefing. San Bernardino Sheriff's Headquarters on Monday, July 27, 2020 in San Bernardino, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protests at Mayor Garcetti's home continue after arrest of demonstrators

item.description: Three people were taken into custody and two were cited Saturday afternoon outside the Windsor Square home of Mayor Eric Garcetti, where protesters converged to demand the mayor cancel rents, according to an LAPD spokesman.
item.content:encoded: Three people were taken into custody and two were cited Saturday afternoon outside the Windsor Square home of Mayor Eric Garcetti, where protesters converged to demand the mayor cancel rents, according to an LAPD spokesman.

item.title: O.C. police review groups want officers to give shooting-related testimony immediately. Chief disagrees
item.dc:creator: Ben Brazil
item.description: Two police oversight groups provided recommendations to the city's police department to have officers provide their testimonies the same day a critical incident occurs rather than within seven days, which is the current policy.
item.content:encoded: Two police oversight groups provided recommendations to the city's police department to have officers provide their testimonies the same day a critical incident occurs rather than within seven days, which is the current policy.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CA., AUGUST 24, 2015: Anaheim police continue to investigate the scene of an officer involved shooting in the 1700 block of West La Palma Avenue in the city of Anaheim August 24, 2016. An Anaheim police officer wounded an armed suspect, 20-year-old Alan-Osvaldo Reza Palamino who was wanted, along with another Anaheim man on suspicion of attempted murder, kidnapping, assault with a deadly weapon and brandishing a firearm (Mark Boster/ Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Search continues for missing servicemen after training accident off Southern California coast
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The amphibious assault vehicle is under hundreds of feet of water, putting it beyond the reach of divers and complicating rescue efforts.
item.content:encoded: The amphibious assault vehicle is under hundreds of feet of water, putting it beyond the reach of divers and complicating rescue efforts.

media:content.media:description: San Clemente Island, viewed from a shuttle aircraft that regularly flies military and civilian personnel to the U.S. Navy-owned land mass 68 miles from San Diego. The military airstrip is seen at the northern end. The southern end has the only remaining ship-to-shore bombardment range in the U.S. The Navy has supported an extensive ecological restoration of endangered plants and animals on the island. [For the record, July 24, 2013: An earlier version of this caption incorrectly said the military airstrip was at the southern end of the island, and the bombardment range to the north.]

item.title: 'Herstory' is out as California revamps K-12 ethnic studies course guide
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Howard Blume
item.description: Officials released on Friday the latest draft of an ethnic studies curriculum, nearly a year after the original version became controversial. The latest iteration retains a primary focus on four racial/ethnic groups but attempts to be more inclusive, while trying to avoid flashpoints related to the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.
item.content:encoded: Officials released on Friday the latest draft of an ethnic studies curriculum, nearly a year after the original version became controversial. The latest iteration retains a primary focus on four racial/ethnic groups but attempts to be more inclusive, while trying to avoid flashpoints related to the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - JANUARY 22, 2018 - Anti-racism signs are seen around a classroom as students work on assignments during an ethnic studies class at John O'Connell High School in San Francisco, California on January 22, 2018. (Josh Edelson / For the Times)

Tabaja moved the barber's chair into the entry way to create a safer environment to cut hair due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After 250 years, Esselen Tribe regains a piece of its ancestral homeland
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.
item.content:encoded: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.

media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by the Western Rivers Conservancy shows lupines on the Adler Ranch in Big Sur on the coast of California south of Monterey. A Native American tribe has reclaimed a small part of ancestral lands on California's Big Sur coast that were lost to Spanish colonial settlement nearly 250 years ago. The Mercury News reports the Esselen Tribe of Monterey County closed escrow on 1,199 acres about 5 miles inland from the ocean that was part of a $4.5 million deal involving the state and the Western Rivers Conservancy. It marks the first restoration of any lands to the tribe. The land encompasses old-growth redwoods, oak woodlands, meadows and endangered steelhead trout. (Doug Steakley/Western Rivers Conservancy via AP)

item.title: 1 Marine dead, 8 troops missing after training accident off Southern California coast
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: An amphibious assault vehicle carrying 15 Marines and one Navy sailor began to take on water during a training exercise, the Marine Corps says.

media:content.media:description: San Clemente Island, viewed from a shuttle aircraft that regularly flies military and civilian personnel to the U.S. Navy-owned land mass 68 miles from San Diego. The military airstrip is seen at the northern end. The southern end has the only remaining ship-to-shore bombardment range in the U.S. The Navy has supported an extensive ecological restoration of endangered plants and animals on the island. [For the record, July 24, 2013: An earlier version of this caption incorrectly said the military airstrip was at the southern end of the island, and the bombardment range to the north.]

item.title: As COVID-19 cases surge, L.A. librarians join the ranks of contact tracers

item.description: Librarians and other library staff in Los Angeles are becoming contact tracers.
item.content:encoded: Librarians and other library staff in Los Angeles are becoming contact tracers.

media:content.media:description: WHITTER, CA - JULY 08: Denice Nossett, one of dozens of librarians in the Los Angeles Public library system who have stepped up to do contact tracing work, poses for a portrait at her home on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Whitter, CA. Nossett is a contact tracing team leader. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fears grow that releasing thousands of California prisoners will spread COVID-19 into communities
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.
item.content:encoded: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -JULY 30, 2020: Roderick Thompson Sr. 35, who was released 9 months early from Avenal State Prison due to the coronavirus outbreak, is photographed outside of Union Station in downtown Los Angeles after arriving there this afternoon on an Amtrak bus. Thompson Sr. had been incarcerated at Avenal State Prison for the past 3 and 1/2 years and was released this morning. He took the train from Hanford to Bakersfield and the bus from Bakersfield to Union Station. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County's tracing team repeatedly failed to detect coronavirus outbreaks at workplaces
item.dc:creator: Melody Petersen
item.description: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA -- MAY 29: Workers exit the building at the Smithfield Foods-owned Farmer John plant on Friday, May 29, 2020, in Vernon, CA. Their, 153 of 1,837 employees tested positive for COVID-19 between March and May, Los Angeles County officials said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: From the staggering toll of the pandemic, a shared story of human kindness emerges
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."
item.content:encoded: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."

media:content.media:description: Wanda DeSelle was among the thousands in California who lost her life to COVID-19

item.content:encoded: County is examining the deaths of two employees at Mission Foods Corp. in Commerce.

Ontario Convention Center on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: An inmate tested positive for COVID-19. Prison staff housed him with uninfected inmates, he says
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod — a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart — that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.
item.content:encoded: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod — a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart — that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.

media:content.media:description: Three federal judges have ordered Gov. Jerry Brown to reduce California's prison population by nearly 10,000 inmates. Above, razor wire obstacles sit atop a fence that surrounds Pleasant Valley State Prison in the Central Valley.

item.title: Orange County Register editor killed in alleged street racing crash
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.
item.content:encoded: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.

media:content.media:description: Orange County Register editor Eugene Harbrecht was killed in a street racing crash on Thursday afternoon.

item.title: La Luz del Mundo church leader faces new rape charges
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.
item.content:encoded: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.

item.content:encoded: Temperatures and the marine layer should be back to normal by Tuesday in L.A.

item.title: Hubert and Kalisa, longtime African lion partners at the L.A. Zoo, are euthanized
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.
item.content:encoded: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.

media:content.media:description: Hubert grooms his longtime companion, Kalisa in March 2018. The 21-year-old African lions were euthanized Thursday July 30, 2020 due to age-related health problems.

item.title: Lawmakers and jobless workers lash out at California's unemployment agency
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.

media:content.media:description: Job seekers wait in line to speak with recruiters at a career fair in Ontario in September.

item.title: Evacuations ordered and Highway 39 closed as fire spreads in Angeles National Forest
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: By 4 p.m., the Dam fire had grown to 240 acres and was 0% contained.
item.content:encoded: By 4 p.m., the Dam fire had grown to 240 acres and was 0% contained.

media:content.media:description: An aerial assault on the Dam Fire on Highway 39 in Azusa.

item.title: L.A. County deputy alleges 'Executioner' gang dominates Compton sheriff station
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Maya Lau
item.description: The allegations revive concerns of inked deputy groups — with monikers such as the Spartans, Regulators and Banditos — operating out of several L.A. County Sheriff's Department stations
item.content:encoded: The allegations revive concerns of inked deputy groups — with monikers such as the Spartans, Regulators and Banditos — operating out of several L.A. County Sheriff's Department stations

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Samuel Aldama admitted as part of a lawsuit this year that he has a skull tattoo on his calf associated with the Compton Station, where he worked. The photo of his tattoo emerged in the lawsuit. The department has a long history with deputy tattoos that officials say represent cliques that promote overly aggressive policing. NOTE: The photo is an exhibit to a motion filed in court by plaintiff Andrew Taylor.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak at USC's fraternity row leaves at least 40 people infected
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Around 40 individuals on USC's fraternity-filled 28th Street have contracted the virus. Both UCLA and USC have reported over 150 positive cases.
item.content:encoded: Around 40 individuals on USC's fraternity-filled 28th Street have contracted the virus. Both UCLA and USC have reported over 150 positive cases.

media:content.media:description: Officers patrol the USC campus in 2012 the day after four people were shot outside a Halloween party by a young man aiming at a rival gang member.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Pasadena apartment fire that killed 4-year-old is blamed on electrical malfunction
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A fire that left a 4-year-old boy dead and his mother and younger brother critically injured is believed to have been caused by an electrical issue.
item.content:encoded: A fire that left a 4-year-old boy dead and his mother and younger brother critically injured is believed to have been caused by an electrical issue.

media:content.media:description: A young child died in a Pasadena apartment fire on Wednesday. His sibling and mother were both critically injured.

item.title: California passes 9,000 coronavirus-related deaths after 2 days of record-setting fatalities

item.content:encoded: As of Thursday evening, California had recorded at least 493,140 coronavirus cases and 9,016 related deaths.

item.title: Men are less likely to wear masks. They are also dying of coronavirus at higher rates in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti said that men account for two-thirds of the virus deaths in L.A. County that have occurred outside of an institutional setting.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti said that men account for two-thirds of the virus deaths in L.A. County that have occurred outside of an institutional setting.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA-CA-JULY 21, 2020: People visit the Santa Monica Pier on Tuesday, July 21, 2020. California has again reported its highest number of coronavirus cases in a single day Monday. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Pension spiking' is not protected by California law, top court rules
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Unions and public employee groups lose their challenge to the ban on 'pension spiking,' which for some created pensions higher than their salaries.
item.content:encoded: Unions and public employee groups lose their challenge to the ban on 'pension spiking,' which for some created pensions higher than their salaries.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Jerry Brown has described pension reform as a "moral obligation." Above, he outlines his 12-point plan in October 2011.

item.title: Hollywood-backed activist endangered pets by treating them with his own products, veterinarians say
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Veterinarians say animal activist Marc Ching persuaded their clients to abandon a prescribed treatment regimen in favor of products he sells at his for-profit pet food store.
item.content:encoded: Veterinarians say animal activist Marc Ching persuaded their clients to abandon a prescribed treatment regimen in favor of products he sells at his for-profit pet food store.

media:content.media:description: STUDIO CITY, CA - JULY 05: Natalia Soto, with her dog Moo, is a veterinarian who raised concerns about Marc Ching giving bad medical advice to pet owners. She was treating a dog that needed surgery to remove bladder stones. She said the dog's owner told her Ching had advised that the stones would dissolve if she gave the pet his supplements, which cost her about $600. Soto photographed at Woodbridge Park on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Studio City, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The Los Angeles River as you've never seen it — in augmented reality
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app, brings you the story of the river from pre-history to the present
item.content:encoded: "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app, brings you the story of the river from pre-history to the present

media:content.media:description: A still from "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app (AR app) tells the story of the L.A. River through a series of interactive visualizations. It was was produced by Verizon Media's RYOT studio, a lab focused on immersive storytelling, in collaboration with Vrai Pictures, a content studio and the production studio Superbright.

item.title: After missing DACA, she resented her U.S.-born siblings. Trump ruined her second chance
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo, Molly O'Toole
item.description: The lack of DACA for more than 65,000 immigrant youth is forever changing the trajectory of their lives.
item.content:encoded: The lack of DACA for more than 65,000 immigrant youth is forever changing the trajectory of their lives.

media:content.media:description: OXNARD, CA - JULY 19: Beatriz Basurto, 19, middle, of Oxnard hands food to Josefa Hernandez, right, age 70, at a food give away on Sunday, July 19, 2020 in Oxnard, CA during the coronavirus pandemic. Several organizations distributed food to mostly local farm workers and their families. Seniors arrived via scooters asking for food. Beatriz Reyes is part of a new generation of immigrants who are eligible for DACA - but left in the dark as Trump tries to end DACA again and refuses to take new applications despite SCOTUS ruling. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: It's time to chop down the 'lynching tree' from this California city's logo
item.dc:creator: Christopher Knight

In the background stand the SoFi Stadium which is still under construction. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Union representing father of Andres Guardado calls on sheriff to resign
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Several advocate groups, including the Unite Here Local 11 union, are calling on L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva to step down, saying he mishandled the investigation into the deputy killing of Andres Guardado and has resisted accountability.
item.content:encoded: Several advocate groups, including the Unite Here Local 11 union, are calling on L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva to step down, saying he mishandled the investigation into the deputy killing of Andres Guardado and has resisted accountability.

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 21: Native American dancers along with hundreds of people rallied and marched outside the Compton Sheriffs' Office in protest for the shooting of Andres Guardado, security guard who was fatally shot by a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy on Sunday, June 21, 2020 in Gardena, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California considers strict 'George Floyd' law to punish police who fail to intervene
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: After officers in Minneapolis failed to stop a colleague from killing George Floyd, California is considering a new law with tough consequences.
item.content:encoded: After officers in Minneapolis failed to stop a colleague from killing George Floyd, California is considering a new law with tough consequences.

media:content.media:description: (Los Angeles, CA) Four coffins in memory of George Floyd and others who were killed by police at 1st and Broadway streets in downtown Los Angeles on June 8, 2020. Joined by interfaith leaders, labor, people of color, immigrants, community members, and victims of police brutality, Black Lives Matter-LA is set to hold a memorial service in Downtown Los Angeles on Monday, June 8, honoring George Floyd and demanding justice for those killed by the hands of the police. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom announces 'strike team' for California's unemployment agency as 1 million await benefits
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Many people who lost jobs or income in California due to coronavirus say they have been unable to get the benefits for which they are eligible.
item.content:encoded: Many people who lost jobs or income in California due to coronavirus say they have been unable to get the benefits for which they are eligible.

media:content.media:description: A job seeker waits to use a phone at a career center in Richmond, Calif. Economist Jack Kyser predicts that the state's jobless rate will average 12.6% next year, but other economists call his prediction overly pessimistic.

item.title: O.C. Board of Education will sue Newsom to reopen schools

item.description: Orange County board of education votes to sue Newsom to reopen schools. Law firm Tyler & Bursch will represent the board
item.content:encoded: Orange County board of education votes to sue Newsom to reopen schools. Law firm Tyler & Bursch will represent the board

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 2020: Spring breakers, visitors and locals walk on the pier amid coronavirus pandemic restrictions downtown Huntington Beach, Calif., on March 18, 2020. Orange County bars, breweries and wineries were ordered to close, restaurants were told to offer take-out or delivery only, and people were told not to gather to curb transmission of the coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. council votes to resume major cleanups near shelters
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Supporters of the decision said it was needed to maintain cleanliness and keep promises that city leaders made to neighbors. Critics said it would put homeless people at greater risk during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Supporters of the decision said it was needed to maintain cleanliness and keep promises that city leaders made to neighbors. Critics said it would put homeless people at greater risk during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES CA JULY 1, 2019 -- Homeless people pack up their belongings along First Street between Broadway and Spring Street during a cleanup Monday morning, July 1, 2019. The area targeted on First Street is the sidewalk in front of a fenced-in empty lot next to a portion of Grand Park used for parking during scheduled events. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Missing a mask? One L.A. politician is ready to fine you $100
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Luke Money
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Paul Koretz is ready to fine people who go out without a mask, saying such measures are needed until there is a vaccine
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Paul Koretz is ready to fine people who go out without a mask, saying such measures are needed until there is a vaccine

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 25: People in downtown Los Angeles on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Los Angeles County Is supposed to reach 90,000 active covid cases today and the state may reach 200,000 cases, with Mayor Eric Garcetti ca;;omg for Angelenos to stay indoors amid the surge in COVID-19 cases.

item.title: L.A. County reports 91 deaths from COVID-19, the most in a single day
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The new numbers brought the county's total confirmed infections to more than 180,000 and death toll to more than 4,500.
item.content:encoded: The new numbers brought the county's total confirmed infections to more than 180,000 and death toll to more than 4,500.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 18: A jogger wears a protective mask to protect from contracting COVID-19 while passing L.A. LIVE Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public or high-risk settings, including when shopping, taking public transit or seeking medical care, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Manuel Henriquez, Bay Area financier, gets six months in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Manuel Henriquez, who was accused of rigging his daughters' exams and bribing a Georgetown tennis coach, is sentenced to six months in prison.
item.content:encoded: Manuel Henriquez, who was accused of rigging his daughters' exams and bribing a Georgetown tennis coach, is sentenced to six months in prison.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019, file photo, Manuel and Elizabeth Henriquez arrive at federal court in Boston to face charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Henriquez and her husband were charged with paying $400,000 in bribes to get their oldest daughter into Georgetown as a bogus tennis recruit in 2016. They also paid bribes to have someone cheat on their daughters' college entrance exams, authorities said. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.title: Heat wave to bake Southern California, creating potential fire danger
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The hot spell will still bake the region Thursday through Saturday with temperatures roughly 10 degrees above normal for this time of year.
item.content:encoded: The hot spell will still bake the region Thursday through Saturday with temperatures roughly 10 degrees above normal for this time of year.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - JUNE 11, 2020. A man wadering a protective mask and a wide-brimmed hat on a warm afternoon at Junipero Beach in Long Beach on Thursday, June 11, 2020. A heat wave is expected to give way to cooler temperatures in coming days. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

(KTLA)

item.title: Dispute between LAUSD and teachers over online learning keeps parents in limbo

item.title: With few options to get home, Chinese students abroad fall victim to ticket scams
item.dc:creator: Xinlu Liang
item.description: With flights home severely limited, Chinese students stuck abroad fall victim to airline ticket scams.
item.content:encoded: With flights home severely limited, Chinese students stuck abroad fall victim to airline ticket scams.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 11: One of several students returning home to China after studying in the U.S. wears a protective suit while waiting for a flight at the Tom Bradley International Terminal, Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) which is now requiring travelers to wear face covering to help keep fellow passengers and crew safe by limiting the spread of the coronavirus Covid-19. The students said they will all wear the same suit but will don the suit after passing thorough security. The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Wearing masks could cut California coronavirus spread in half, top health official says

(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California again breaks record for most coronavirus deaths in a single day

item.content:encoded: California reported 167 deaths Tuesday. It's the third time this month that California has broken a single-day record for deaths.

media:content.media:description: NATIONAL CITY, CA - JULY 08: Nurse Kyah Paschall checks on 64-year-old-coronavirus patient Patricia Luera connected to a ventilator at Paradise Valley Hospital, National City. Patricia's husband Pedro Luera is also suffering from coronavirus is under treatment and breathing through ventilator in the same unit of the hospital. Both were airlifted by Mercy Air ambulances to National City.(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Who should choose UC campus chancellors? Faculty protest proposal to reduce their role

item.content:encoded: University of California faculty leaders oppose a proposal they say would significantly reduce their role in searches for campus chancellors.

item.title: California won't conquer the coronavirus, and fully reopen, until it can protect essential workers
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Anita Chabria
item.description: It's becoming increasingly clear that California is not going to conquer the coronavirus until it dramatically improves safety measures for essential workers at the epicenter of the health crisis.
item.content:encoded: It's becoming increasingly clear that California is not going to conquer the coronavirus until it dramatically improves safety measures for essential workers at the epicenter of the health crisis.

media:content.media:description: Jose Farias, who's infected with Covid-19, stands in the doorway of a recuperative care center for homeless infected with the coronavirus at the Gospel Rescue Mission in Stockton, California on July 22, 2020. More than 70% of new cases of coronavirus in California's fertile San Joaquin valley are Latino workers, but advocates say they lack testing and access to care.

item.title: Meet Perseverance, JPL's newest Mars rover
item.dc:creator: Deborah Netburn
item.description: Perseverance, NASA's newest Mars rover, is living up to its name. It has already survived a hurdle no previous rover has had to face: a global pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Perseverance, NASA's newest Mars rover, is living up to its name. It has already survived a hurdle no previous rover has had to face: a global pandemic.

media:content.media:description: An illustration of NASA's Perseverance rover on the surface of Mars.

item.title: Health crisis looming inside a health crisis: People are avoiding going to the doctor
item.dc:creator: John M. Glionna
item.description: Americans are avoiding hospitals and clinics, even when they shouldn't be. Experts expect a jump in preventable diseases after the pandemic eases.
item.content:encoded: Americans are avoiding hospitals and clinics, even when they shouldn't be. Experts expect a jump in preventable diseases after the pandemic eases.

media:content.media:description: Just 43% of adults with hypertension had their blood pressure under control, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control.

item.title: Coronavirus surge turns the Southland inside out
item.description: Second wave of coronavirus has businesses and the public moving from indoors to the great outdoors
item.content:encoded: Second wave of coronavirus has businesses and the public moving from indoors to the great outdoors

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 17: The outdoor dining scene at Yakitoriya on Friday, July 17, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Mariah Tauger / Los Angeles Times / prop styling Kate Kuo)

item.title: L.A. County shuts down three food businesses over unreported COVID-19 outbreaks
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Maya Lau
item.description: The move comes amid increased enforcement against businesses failing to comply with coronavirus rules.
item.content:encoded: The move comes amid increased enforcement against businesses failing to comply with coronavirus rules.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MARCH 10, 2020: Dr. Barbara Ferrer is the director of the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health. She gives her daily update on Tuesday. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: Less stress, better grades: With schools closed, some kids thrive
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: When the pandemic caused schools to shutter, some students relished more free time, less-stressful classes and a lack of bullying.
item.content:encoded: When the pandemic caused schools to shutter, some students relished more free time, less-stressful classes and a lack of bullying.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 24: From Left - Sebastian Hernandez, 15 and his brother, Benjamin Hernandez, 12, pose for a portrait during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, May 24, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. While some kids are stressed, confused, bored and isolated during quarantine, the Hernandez brothers have relished the opportunity to slow down. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California fires prompt evacuations as they explode in size and threaten homes
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The Branch fire in San Luis Obispo County grew to nearly 3,000 acres; the Gold fire is burning almost 22,000 acres; the Hog fire in Lassen County is 72% contained.
item.content:encoded: The Branch fire in San Luis Obispo County grew to nearly 3,000 acres; the Gold fire is burning almost 22,000 acres; the Hog fire in Lassen County is 72% contained.

media:content.media:description: The Branch fire in San Luis Obispo County grew to nearly 3,000 acres on Tuesday evening, threatening structures in the rural area.

item.title: California could create its own $600 weekly unemployment benefit
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Assemblyman Phil Ting said there is support for providing up to $600 weekly to jobless Californians
item.content:encoded: Assemblyman Phil Ting said there is support for providing up to $600 weekly to jobless Californians

media:content.media:description: Assemblyman Phil Ting, D-San Francisco, right, chair of the Assembly budget committee discusses the state budget agreement reached between Gov. Jerry Brown and Democratic lawmakers, Tuesday, June 13, 2017, in Sacramento, Calif. Mitchell was accompanied Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon, D-Paramount. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: L.A. could pull money away from fund tied to beleaguered Councilman Jose Huizar
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. lawmakers could yank money away from a fund that was controlled by the office of Councilman Jose Huizar, who has been accused of heading a pay-to-play scheme.
item.content:encoded: L.A. lawmakers could yank money away from a fund that was controlled by the office of Councilman Jose Huizar, who has been accused of heading a pay-to-play scheme.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles City Ethics Commission has fined lobbyist John Ek $11,000 for inviting city officials to a birthday party at a downtown restaurant.

item.title: Palm Springs orders all restaurants, bars to close early
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Palm Springs bars, wineries and restaurants will have to close early due to the coronavirus, a new city order dictates.
item.content:encoded: Palm Springs bars, wineries and restaurants will have to close early due to the coronavirus, a new city order dictates.

media:content.media:description: PALM SPRINGS, CA - JULY 16, 2020: Unmasked customers enjoy the outdoor seating at the Marlin Bar downtown Palm Springs on July 16, 2020 in Riverside County, California. Riverside County is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With ouster of priest accused of pedophilia, Coptic Church confronts sexual abuse
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: The Coptic Orthodox Church in the U.S., shaken by accusations of sexual abuse, has vowed to end inappropriate behavior in its cloistered communities.
item.content:encoded: The Coptic Orthodox Church in the U.S., shaken by accusations of sexual abuse, has vowed to end inappropriate behavior in its cloistered communities.

media:content.media:description: Pope Tawadros II, leader of Egypt's Coptic Church, leads an Easter service at the Cathedral of Abbasiya in Cairo.

item.title: Texas man charged with murder in Hollywood street race shooting that left teen girl dead
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Ramon Roque Monreal of El Paso has been charged with murder in connection with a Hollywood shooting that left a teenage girl dead
item.content:encoded: Ramon Roque Monreal of El Paso has been charged with murder in connection with a Hollywood shooting that left a teenage girl dead

media:content.media:description: Illegal Street racing activities on Ana Street in Compton on Apr. 13.

item.title: California Legislature to consider new tax on millionaires for schools, other services
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Assembly Bill 1253 would impose a new 1% surcharge on adjusted income starting at $1 million, increasing to 3% for those who earn more than $2 million and rising to 3.5% on income above $5 million.
item.content:encoded: Assembly Bill 1253 would impose a new 1% surcharge on adjusted income starting at $1 million, increasing to 3% for those who earn more than $2 million and rising to 3.5% on income above $5 million.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)
